Hey guys, I turned 50 last week.

If you have been listening to my podcast, you already know that midlife and I have had a complicated relationship. And honestly, for a long time, I was not sure if I wanted to make a big deal out of this birthday. There are headlines every day about how 50 is the new 30. And friends, they annoy me. I do not need to be 30 again. I do not even want to be 30 again. 30 was chaotic. 30 was defined by pressure to achieve and pressure to pretend I had everything under control. So the more I thought about it, the clearer it became that 50 is not a replacement age. It is not a rerun or a second chance at youth. 50 is its own season. And I wanted to greet it as myself, not as some younger version I was supposed to channel. Weâ€™re told to hide our age, that itâ€™s rude to ask women how old we are. Iâ€™m done hiding my age. I am 50 and damn proud of it!

On top of that, so often us women spend a whole lot of time and money planning our weddings, planning our kidsâ€™ birthdays (iykyk), but we donâ€™t spend it celebrating ourselves. I decided I wanted to put in that same amount of time and energy with friends and family to celebrate my own personal milestoneâ€¦ with lots and lots of dancing.

So I bit the bullet. I planned a girls trip. I planned a party (with help from my husband Nihal). Everyone there helped get me where I am, and I wanted to celebrate them just as much. I did something that felt brave in its own simple way: I let myself be seen. I bought a stunning gold dress. I had the audacity to want to be celebrated. And here is what I learned: You should ABSOLUTELY make a big deal out of the moments that matter to you. You should let the people who love you surround you with joy even if your instinct is to downplay your needs.

I hope this is a reminder to all of you out there to celebrate your life. So if you are on the fence about celebrating yourself, consider this your gentle nudge. I hope you choose to honor your happiness. I hope you celebrate your milestones. I hope you let your village show up for you. And I hope you trust that you are worth celebrating.

This week on my Substack, I dive into one of my all-time favorite myths with economist Corinne Low, author of the new book â€˜Having It Allâ€™.

Hereâ€™s what she brilliantly broke down for me:

Economists divide the world into two spheres: market production (the work thatâ€™s paid and counted) and home production (the work that isnâ€™t). Both are essential to society, but only one shows up in GDP.

For most of history, women did the home production and men did the market work. Then came the feminist revolution, and women entered the market. The problem? Men never entered the home.

So now, women do both.

We doubled our market participation without halving our home responsibilities. Thatâ€™s what Corinne calls the â€œsqueezeâ€ â€” the strain we feel when we juggle working both in the market and the home. And itâ€™s baked into the very economics of how we live and work. Every hour women spend on unpaid labor at home is an hour we canâ€™t spend competing in the marketplace.

And yet when women try to adjust â€” by going part-time, freelancing, or choosing more flexible jobs â€” those decisions get framed as personal failings instead of natural consequences of the flaws in our structural design.

The idea of â€œhaving it allâ€ was supposed to be aspirational, but itâ€™s always been an accounting error.

To â€œhave it all,â€ youâ€™d need to live in an economy that values both forms of production â€” home and market â€” equally. Youâ€™d need workplaces that recognize care as infrastructure, not interference. Youâ€™d need partners who share the load.

Instead, we live in a system that still assumes someone else (and most often, a woman) is doing the invisible labor. And when sheâ€™s not, it all falls apart.

Imposter syndrome is a lie. And for all the history nerds out there, here's one of my favorite history lessons to break it all down!

Recently, during my conversation at Harvey Mudd College to discuss the crisis of disconnection, someone in the audience asked me for advice on how women can overcome imposter syndrome.

If you've been following me for a while, you might know that that's a question people ask me all the time. And in fact, I gave a whole graduation speech about it at Smith College! The thing is, it's sort of a trick question. Because to me, the best way to overcome "imposter syndrome" is to recognize that it's all a lie in the first place! It doesn't mean that your feelings aren't valid. But it does require seeing it for the myth that it is. Imposter syndrome, like bicycle face before it, is another tactic to dissuade women from making progress.

The next time someone with power tries to make you feel like you didn't earn your seat at the table, remember that that's all a strategy.

And it shouldn't take a PhD in economics to figure out some of the reasons why.

The cost of child care is too damn high!

It's not that women are suddenly deciding to quit their jobs. They're being forced out!

That's why we need the public AND the private sector to treat child care like the economic imperative that it is.

My organization, Moms First, is working to fix this. And we'd love for you to join us!

Thank you to Holly Corbett for including me in this important story in Forbes. I'll share the full link in my comments.

And, I definitely had expectations in my head of exactly how the scene would play out at home for the big reveal.

Then, reality laughed at the plans I had made.

My youngest, Sai, wanted to watchÂ Peppa Pig.Â Shaan, my oldest, playfully grabbed the remote in a game of keep-away. I got mad. They got madder. Suddenly we were in a big argument in separate corners of the room negotiating screen time instead of watching my big moment unfold. And in the cartoonish tornado of flying words and objects (somehow tiny socks were launched in the air?), the segment had come and gone.

And truthfully, Iâ€™m still figuring out how to hold both things at once: the pride and the frustration, the joy and the chaos. How to let the big moments be messy and still mean something.

full_text:
Friends,

This was a hard year.

A year of war and fear, of democratic backsliding and institutional silence. A year when too many powerful people chose comfort over courage and neutrality over humanity. I watched institutions I believed in hedge, delay, and look away. I saw how quickly values can collapse when they become inconvenient.

And what kept me going was watching women act anyway, the odds and the outcomes be damned.

Again and again this year, women stepped forward when it cost them something. Their jobs. Their safety. Their privacy. Their reputations. They did not wait for permission or consensus. They did not ask whether the moment was good for their brand. They saw harm, or opportunity to do good, and they refused to be quiet.

Some of this bravery happened on the biggest stages in the world. Some of it happened in courtrooms, classrooms, daycare centers, studios, and hospital rooms. Some of it came from women whose names you know. Some came from women who will never be protected by power or praised by the press.

That is the kind of bravery I want to honor this year. Not perfection. Not heroics. Bravery that looks like staying human inside systems that reward cruelty. Bravery that looks like telling the truth when silence would be safer. Bravery that shows up in care work, in creativity, in science, in justice, and in motherhood.

This list is not exhaustive and it is not ranked. It is just a tiny offering of gratitude despite the immutable noise that constantly asks us, in surround sound, to dismiss and vilify each other.

So thank you to the women who reminded me, in a year that tested so much, that bravery still exists. And yes, it matters.

Ok all, let's dive into the so-called "ambition gap" between men and women at work.

A new report from Lean In and McKinsey & Company shows that for the first time in the report's 10-year history, significantly fewer women than men want a promotion at work.

Compared with 80% of men in entry-level career stages, 86% in mid-career, and 92% of senior execs, only 69% of women in entry-level stages, 82% mid-career, and 84% of women senior execs reported a desire to advance in their careers.

This is what's been called the "ambition gap."

Here's the thing: it's not exactly a mystery. This is the logical outcome of the past year of companies backsliding on their commitments to women in the workplace.

Women aren't losing ambition. We're just paying attention.

But it doesn't have to be this way.

Moms First is here and on the case. Join us!
